text: What material is most commonly used for fabricating metal castings in removable partial dentures (RPDs)?
explanation:
Removable Partial Denture (RPD) Casting Alloys

Overview:
The metal framework of an RPD requires strength, rigidity, and corrosion resistance while remaining lightweight and economical. Base metal alloys meet these requirements and are the most commonly used for RPD frameworks.

Common Alloys:
  • Cobalt–chromium (Co–Cr): High strength, rigidity, low weight.
  • Nickel–chromium (Ni–Cr): Similar but may cause allergic reactions.
  • Titanium: Biocompatible, but difficult to cast.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Material of choice: Base metal alloys (usually Co–Cr).
  • Advantages: Strong, rigid, lightweight, corrosion-resistant, affordable.
  • Disadvantages: Hard to polish, potential nickel allergy.

text: In a Kennedy Class I removable partial denture, what is the main function of the rests placed on canines or premolars anterior to the edentulous areas?
option1: To provide vertical support to the denture base
option2: To act as indirect retainers that prevent lifting of the distal extension base
option3: To locate the axis of rotation (fulcrum line)
option4: To provide direct retention against horizontal dislodgment
explanation:
Indirect Retainers and the Fulcrum Line in Distal Extension RPDs

Overview:
In distal extension RPDs (Kennedy Class I and II), the base tends to rotate around a fulcrum line through the posterior rests. Indirect retainers—usually anterior rests—resist this lifting movement.

Key Concepts:
  • Fulcrum line: Passes through terminal abutment rests.
  • Indirect retainers: Placed anterior and perpendicular to that line (e.g., on canines or premolars).
  • Function: Prevent lifting of the distal extension base (tissue-ward rotation).
  • All rests provide vertical support; indirect retainers specifically prevent rotation.

text: Who developed the classification system for removable partial dentures based on the location of edentulous areas?
explanation:
Kennedy Classification of Removable Partial Dentures

Overview:
The Kennedy classification (developed by Dr. Edward Kennedy) describes the edentulous pattern in an arch and guides RPD design.

The Four Main Classes:
  • Class I: Bilateral distal extension.
  • Class II: Unilateral distal extension.
  • Class III: Bounded edentulous space.
  • Class IV: Single anterior edentulous area crossing the midline.

Clinical Significance:
  • Determines support and rotation patterns.
  • Guides placement of major connectors, rests, and indirect retainers.
  • Class I and II require tissue support and indirect retention; Class III is tooth-supported.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Developer: Dr. Edward Kennedy.
  • Purpose: Classify edentulous patterns for RPD design.
  • Applegate: Added modification rules (none for Class IV).

text: What is the primary purpose of rest seats in a removable partial denture (RPD)?
explanation:
Purpose of Rest Seats in Removable Partial Dentures

Overview:
A rest seat is prepared on an abutment tooth to receive the rest component of an RPD. Its primary role is vertical support, directing occlusal forces along the long axis of the tooth.

Key Points:
  • Prevents denture from moving tissue-ward under load.
  • Transfers forces to abutment teeth for stability.
  • Maintains occlusal relationships and prevents tissue impingement.

Support vs. Other Functions:
  • Support: Rests and rest seats.
  • Stability: Guide planes and rigid connectors.
  • Retention: Clasps engaging undercuts.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Main function: Support.
  • Design: Directs occlusal load along tooth’s long axis.

text: What is the most common cause of a gag reflex in a patient wearing new complete dentures?
option2: Overextended posterior border of the maxillary denture
option4: Underextended lingual flange of the mandibular denture
explanation:
Gag Reflex in Denture Patients

A gag reflex commonly occurs when the posterior border of a maxillary denture extends too far back, contacting the soft palate beyond the vibrating line. This overstimulation of the movable soft palate triggers a reflexive gagging response.

Key Concept:
  • The vibrating line marks the junction of the hard and soft palate.
  • The denture should terminate just anterior to this line to achieve a proper seal without touching movable tissue.
  • Extension too far posteriorly → gagging and discomfort.

Other Common Denture Complications:
  • Sore throat: Mandibular overextension distally.
  • Loss of retention: Underextended borders or inadequate seal.
  • Soreness of ridge: Overpressure or poor tissue adaptation.
  • Speech difficulty: Over-thick palatal area or improper tooth position.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Main cause of gagging: Overextended posterior border beyond vibrating line.
  • Fix: Shorten border to stop at vibrating line.
  • Location: Between hard and soft palate junction.

text: A patient was recently given complete dentures for both jaws. Within a few days, she complained of cheek biting. What is the most likely reason?
option4: Posterior teeth set too far lingually
explanation:
Cheek Biting in Complete Denture Patients

Cheek biting occurs most often due to a decrease in vertical dimension of occlusion (VDO) or improper tooth positioning.

Mechanism:
  • When VDO is reduced, the buccal mucosa folds inward, allowing it to get caught between teeth.
  • Posterior teeth placed too far buccally also increase soft tissue interference.

Management:
  • Re-establish proper VDO.
  • Recontour buccal surfaces to guide cheeks away.
  • Check occlusal contacts and harmony.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Main cause: Decreased VDO or buccal tooth placement.
  • Correction: Adjust VDO and contour polished surfaces.

text: A patient with a complete mandibular denture complains of a localized burning sensation in the lower ridge region. What is the most likely cause?
option4: Poor saliva flow causing mucosal irritation
explanation:
Localized Burning Sensation Under Mandibular Denture

A burning or sharp painpressure on the mental foramen caused by ridge resorption.

Mechanism:
  • As the ridge resorbs, the mental nerve becomes superficial.
  • The denture base compresses the nerve, producing burning or tingling pain.

Management:
  • Relieve pressure in the foramen area.
  • Rebase or reline denture for better adaptation.
  • Consider implant-supported overdenture for severe resorption.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Most likely cause: Pressure on the mental foramen.
  • Common in: Severely resorbed ridges.
  • Treatment: Relieve denture pressure and adjust fit.

text: What feature of a crown preparation helps prevent fracture in a lithium disilicate crown?
explanation:
Preventing Fracture in Lithium Disilicate Crowns

Lithium disilicate crowns are strong but brittle. Rounded internal line angles help distribute stress evenly and reduce crack propagation.

Preparation Guidelines:
  • Axial reduction: 1.0–1.5 mm.
  • Occlusal reduction: 1.5–2.0 mm.
  • Finish line: Shoulder or deep chamfer with smooth internal angle.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Prevents fracture: Rounded internal line angles.
  • Reason: Reduces stress concentration within ceramic.
  • Other requirements: Uniform reduction and smooth finish lines.

text: What is the ideal ferrule length for a crown preparation to provide optimal resistance and fracture strength?
explanation:
The Ferrule Effect in Crown Preparations

A ferrule is a band of tooth structure encircling the cervical portion of a preparation that enhances resistance and fracture strength, especially in endodontically treated teeth.

Ideal Ferrule Design:
  • Height: At least 2 mm of sound tooth structure circumferentially above the margin.
  • Thickness: Minimum 1 mm of dentin wall thickness.
  • Finish line: On sound tooth structure (not on core).

High-Yield Summary:
  • Ideal ferrule height: 2 mm.
  • Effect: Improves fracture resistance and retention.
  • Without ferrule: Tooth more prone to fracture.

text: When preparing a post and core, what is the most important factor to consider for long-term success?
explanation:
Post and Core Design – Key Determinant of Success

The amount of remaining tooth structure is the most critical factor for success. Posts do not strengthen the tooth—they only retain the core.

Key Principles:
  • Preserve maximum dentin, especially the cervical ferrule area.
  • Ferrule: At least 2 mm of circumferential tooth structure for resistance.
  • Every millimeter of remaining dentin increases fracture resistance.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Most important factor: Remaining tooth structure (ferrule effect).
  • Posts retain the core—they do not reinforce the root.
  • Goal: Preserve dentin and achieve a 2 mm ferrule.

text: A patient experiences a Class II Ellis fracture involving enamel and dentin but no pulp exposure. What is the best immediate treatment option?
option1: Root canal treatment followed by composite restoration
option2: Direct composite restoration with dentin protection
explanation:
Ellis Class II Fracture – Enamel and Dentin Involvement

A Class II Ellis fracture extends into dentin but does not expose the pulp. The goal is to protect dentin and preserve vitality.

Treatment:
  • Cover exposed dentin with calcium hydroxide liner or resin-modified glass ionomer.
  • Restore with direct composite to seal dentinal tubules.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Ellis Class II: Enamel + dentin (no pulp exposure).
  • Immediate treatment: Protect dentin (CaOH liner) + composite restoration.
  • Goal: Maintain pulp vitality and function.

text: Which cement is most commonly used for the cementation of inlays and onlays?
explanation:
Cementation of Inlays and Onlays

Resin cements are most commonly used due to their high bond strength, low solubility, and esthetic properties.

Why Resin Cement?
  • Strong adhesion to both tooth and restoration.
  • Light-cured for thin restorations, dual-cured for thicker ones.
  • Excellent marginal seal and durability.

Alternatives:
  • Glass ionomer: Fluoride release but weaker and more soluble.
  • Zinc phosphate: Strong compressive strength, no adhesion.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Most common: Resin cement.
  • Advantages: Strong, adhesive, esthetic, low solubility.
  • Dual-cure resin: Ideal for thick or opaque restorations.

text: What is the primary purpose of a die in the crown fabrication process?
option1: To check the occlusion of the provisional crown
option2: To provide a replica of the prepared tooth for precise crown fabrication
option3: To record the opposing arch during impression taking
option4: To mount casts on the articulator for jaw relation records
explanation:
The Die in Crown and Bridge Fabrication

A die is an accurate, removable reproduction of a single prepared tooth made from an impression. It allows the technician to fabricate a crown, inlay, or onlay with precise margin adaptation and occlusal fit.

Process:
  • Impression: Detailed impression of the prepared tooth is made using elastomeric material (PVS or polyether).
  • Pouring: Impression is poured in Type IV or V dental stone to form the working cast.
  • Die sectioning: The prepared tooth area is separated or pinned to create a removable die.
  • Margin trimming: Technician carefully exposes the finish line for visibility during wax-up.
  • Wax pattern: Crown or inlay is built directly on this die to ensure accuracy of fit.

Key Properties of a Good Die:
  • High dimensional accuracy and low expansion.
  • Hard, abrasion-resistant surface (Type IV gypsum or epoxy resin).
  • Clearly visible margin for precise adaptation.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Purpose: Exact replica of the prepared tooth for accurate crown fit.
  • Material: Type IV dental stone (high strength, low expansion).
  • Importance: Precision of die = accuracy of final restoration.

text: Which statement about a cantilever bridge is most accurate?
option1: It distributes occlusal forces evenly across multiple abutments
option2: It is supported by abutment teeth only on one side of the edentulous space
option3: It has better stress distribution than a conventional fixed partial denture
option4: It is primarily indicated for replacement of posterior molars
explanation:
Cantilever Bridge – Overview

A cantilever bridge replaces a missing tooth but is supported only on one side of the edentulous space. It acts like a lever, concentrating stress on the abutment tooth.

Biomechanics:
  • Forces on the pontic create a bending moment on the abutment.
  • Can lead to tipping or periodontal strain if poorly designed.
  • Stress distribution is less favorable than in conventional bridges.

Clinical Use:
  • Indicated mainly in the anterior region (e.g., replacing a maxillary lateral incisor).
  • Abutment should have strong periodontal support and long roots.
  • Avoid in posterior areas with high occlusal loads.

Design Principles:
  • Rigid connectors minimize flexure.
  • Occlusal contacts should be light and controlled.
  • Use multiple abutments if possible to share stress.

High-Yield Summary:
  • Definition: Supported by abutments on only one side of the missing tooth.
  • Common site: Maxillary anterior region.
  • Disadvantage: Stress concentration on abutment.
  • Avoid in: Posterior or heavy occlusion cases.
